discussion.content:
Integer-> Long -> Double -> Decimal.
Integer can be defined as Double but Double can't be defined as Integer.
C is correct

questions.question_text: Which is a valid Apex assignment?

discussion.content:
Correct.
Percentage in apex is translated as numbers, so 50% is 50 in apex

Selected Answer: D
It explicitly said the object is with length 2 and 0 decimal places. So the custom object is between 0-99. So it's 50. And then the acctScore is custom object * 100. Therefore it will be 5000 in this case.

Selected Answer: D
D Correct

Selected Answer: D
D 100%. I tested it

Selected Answer: B
Percents are also their own data type—a number with a percent sign attached. A Percent is stored as a number divided by 100, meaning that 100% is represented as 1, 90% as 0.9, and so on.

Source: https://trailhead.salesforce.com/content/learn/modules/advanced_formulas/numbers_formulas
Can we get a source for the answer D?

Selected Answer: B
https://trailhead.salesforce.com/content/learn/modules/advanced_formulas/numbers_formulas

Percents are also their own data type—a number with a percent sign attached. A Percent is stored as a number divided by 100, meaning that 100% is represented as 1, 90% as 0.9, and so on.

comments.content: Not right, answer is D. When a percentage field is retrieved, it retrieves just the number part. So 50% will show as 50, which when multiplied by 100 will be 5000.
This is wrong because in Formula, it behaves like an actual percentage but in Apex, it behave like a number, without the "%"

questions.question_text: Which situation prevents a developer from setting sharing rules for a custom object?

discussion.content:
Another source lists B as the correct answer.

If a record is on the detail side of a M/D relationship, you cannot set its sharing settings, as it will inherit the parent record's settings.

I think B is fine
In the list that you provided Custom Objects controlled by parent ( detail in Master Detail relationship) can not have sharing rule.

Selected Answer: B
`b is correct.detail side object records inherits sharing settings from master record

Selected Answer: B
D would not be correct. Shouldn't the owner be of User type only?

comments.content: It should be Public Readonly or Private. But A is Read/Write.

discussion.content: I don't understand why A is not the right answer? If this is completely Public access then it's not possible to extend it, right?

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer

https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.overview_of_custom_object_relationships.htm&type=5

choices.B: The object is on the detail side of a Master-Detail relationship.
choices.A: The object's Sharing Settings is set to Public Read/Write.
choices.C: The developer is not a System Administrator.
choices.D: The object is referenced in an Owner field of a Master-Detail relationship.
